title: Ticket #5688: Add JSON parsing/unparsing for ClassAds
description:
JSON is a popular data format that's very similar to ClassAds, with lists and records of simple data values that can be nested arbitrarily. It would be very handy to parse JSON in ClassAds and vice versa.

The main difference between ClassAds and JSON is that JSON doesn't support expressions with operators or functions. We can address this difference by representing expressions in JSON as decorated strings that can be recognized by the JSON-to-ClassAd parser.

Differences between ClassAds and JSON

  • Simple data types
    • ClassAds have absolute and relative time types.
    • ClassAds have the Error value.
    • JSON does not make a strong distinction between integer and floating point numbers. Special values like Inf or NaN are not allowed.
    • The ClassAds value Undefined can be mapped to JSON's null.
    • JSON strings allow Unicode characters. In UTF-8 encoding (the default), most characters don't require an escape sequence. ClassAd strings are ASCII, with an escape notation for 8-bit non-ASCII values.
  • Records (ClassAds vs JSON objects)
    • The names in JSON objects are case-sensitive. Implementations can choose whether to preserve order and how to handle duplicate names.
  • Expressions
    • JSON doesn't support operators or functions.

For all data types in ClassAds that cannot be directly represented in JSON, we will represent them as annotated strings that the JSON->ClassAd parser can recognize and restore to their original form. We are borrowing an idea that Microsoft used to represent dates as a special data types (http://weblogs.asp.net/bleroy/dates-and-json).

In JSON, forward slash is one of the characters that can be escaped by a back slash inside a string, even though there's no need to do so. We can use this odd feature to represent an expression as a string in such a way that we can recognize it as something other than a simple string if we parse the JSON back into ClassAds.

Here is how we'd represent the expression A + B in JSON: 

"\/Expr(A + B)\/"

If our JSON-to-ClassAd parser sees this string, it will parse the text between the parentheses as normal ClassAd syntax. Other JSON parsers will treat it as a normal string.

All ClassAd values should round-trip properly when rendered as JSON and read back directly. If the JSON text is parsed and unparsed by some other JSON library, then expressions may not be recognized, as they may no longer have the escaped slashes. Also, the distinction between integer and real numbers may be lost (integer becomes real or vice versa).

JSON text can suffer some damage when round-tripped through ClassAds. Duplicate item names and ordering of items in an object are not preserved, but this is allowed by the JSON spec. If a JSON object contains multiple items whose names vary only in alphabetic case, then only one of the items will remain. This is not allowed by the spec.
remarks:
2016-May-31 14:54:54 by jfrey:
The new -json option to condor_q and condor_status prints multiple JSON objects with only a newline for separation. The JSON parser for ClassAds will read this back properly, returning one ad each time it's invoked. But the output as a whole is not a valid JSON document. If that is a concern, we could insert a more-easily recognizable separator between objects or render the entire output as a list of objects (with list begin/end characters at the start and end).
